*I* feel your pain, frets, because it *is* frustrating trying to sort through all the conflicting info.As regards insulin, I actually had a doc tell me that if I got tired of controlling my diet she could prescribe me insulin and then I could eat what I want if I learned how to adjust the insulin doses. I was furious and got a new doc... I want to *avoid* taking insulin, and really avoid taking any meds if I can safely do so by controlling my diet and lifestyle.Anyway, the others who posted are right... the most important thing is that you *are* doing the right things and you have your "stats" under good control.  Diabetes is different for each of us; some have to avoid all sugars to keep good bs control, others are ok with a moderate carb intake, etc etc...  the best thing you can do for yourself is literally monitor what you eat and how it effects your blood sugar, then you can know what works well for your body and what doesn't.As a general rule, lower carb foods, high fiber, and limiting unhealthy foods (snack foods, sweets, alcohol), and maintaining a good weight, moderate exercise, and keeping as happy an outlook on life as you can muster are all a good start.... I also think a frustrated rant is healthy now and again too.  ;-)

Oh yeah... the whole glycemic index vs glycemic load... the nutritionists I have come to trust really feel you need *both*...  the gi tells you how quickly a food's carbs are turned into sugar, well, kind of...bah, instead of me trying to explain it and confuse y'all more, here are some decent summary sites about this:http://www.tshc.fsu.edu/he/nutrition/Nutrition_Specialneeds/glycemic_index.htmhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glycemic_loadhttp://www.brighamandwomens.org/healtheweightforwomen/special_topics/intelihealth1002.aspx?subID=submenu10

You have done the important thing lost weight.  I did that and did it by walking and watching what I ate.  I do believe all diabetics have to stick to the same foods.  However it is important to keep doing what you did.  I messed up when I moved to a big city where I was not able to take my walks, still watched what I ate.  I gained some of the weight back after after about 10 years and now am on insulin, both Lantus and Humilin R.  Am starting my walking again and getting under control.  Whatever you do keep in touch with your doctor and keep from gaining the weight back.  ( By the way when I was diagnosed I was put on pills)  That didn't help till I started to walk and then I was off all medications for over 8 years.  Good luck to you.

question: I was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes about 10 months ago.My doctor's instructions-Metformin twice a day,strict diet and exercise for weight loss,& use the internet to gain as much information on the disease as possible.I lost 45 lbs,A1c is now 6.3,& blood sugar and pressure levels are well within commonly acknowleged safe ranges.I am frankly angry and frustrated over the blatent lack of consensus and contradictory info on safe diabetic nutrition from these sources,all authored (it seems)by self-proclaimed 'expert' dieticians and ADA card carrying MD's.In particular-The info is directed at insulin dependent diabetics,rather than those,such as myself, who need to know specifically what differences(if any) in food intake we need to follow in order to avoid going on insulin.As a low income person without health insurance,the prospect of simply having to become a human pin cushion is unpleasant enough.But having to pay $4000 to $5000 a year out-of-pocket for insulin,testing strips,syringes,constant blood tests etc would leave me homeless--effectively,a death sentence. Any insight would be greatly appreciated. Thanks
